children.name: proud
children.definition: /praʊd/  someone who is proud of their achievements, their school, their family etc is very pleased with them and feels that they are very good or special:
examples: tự hào , hãnh diện
▪ I felt so proud when my son went up to collect his medal.
▪ the proud parents with their new baby
proud of:tự hào , hãnh diện về
▪ Jane’s very proud of her new car.
▪ My students have worked hard, and I’m proud of them.
proud to be/do something:tự hào , hãnh diện khi làm cái gì đó
▪ Morris was proud to be part of such a brilliant team.
▪ I’m proud to say that all my children had a good education.
proud that:tự hào , hãnh diện rằng
▪ He’s very proud that his work has finally been published.
proudly[adverb]:tự hào , hãnh diện
▪ She turned to the crowd, proudly holding up the silver cup.

children.name: take pride in
children.definition: /teɪk ˈpraɪd ɪn/  to feel proud of your work, your appearance etc, and always try to keep it at a high standard:
examples: tự hào về
▪ I’ve always taken pride in my appearance.
▪ The people of the Basque country take great pride in their local cuisine.
take pride in doing something :tự hào khi làm cái gì đó
▪ Teachers should take pride in improving the display work in their classrooms.

children.name: pride yourself on
children.definition: /ˈpraɪd jɔːʳself ɒn/  to be especially proud of something that you do well or of a particular quality that you have:tự hào
examples: ▪ Archer prided himself on his knowledge of Italian art.
pride yourself on doing something:tự hào khi làm cái gì đó
▪ She prides herself on getting things done quickly.
▪ Our staff pride themselves on offering guests a warm welcome.

children.name: sb’s pride and joy
children.definition: somebody’s pride and joy/ somebodyˈs ˌpraɪd ən ˈdʒɔɪ/  if something that you own, something that you have made etc is your pride and joy, you are especially proud of it and it is very important to you:niềmtự hào , hãnh diện của ai đó
examples: ▪ Todd’s magnificent Rolls Royce had been his pride and joy for many years.
▪ The garden was my father’s pride and joy, the real expression of his creativity.
▪ Christina was an only child, her parents’ pride and joy.

children.name: the pride of st
children.definition: the pride of something/ðə ˈpraɪd ɒv something/  the one thing or person in a particular group or place that people are most proud of:tự hào , hãnh diện vì cái gì đó
examples: ▪ Bolton’s famous football team was the pride of the town.
▪ The Mary Rose, which was the pride of Henry VIII’s fleet, sank on her maiden voyage.

children.name: conceited/ big-headed
children.definition: conceited/big-headed/kənˈsiːtɪd, kənˈsiːtəd, ˌbɪg ˈhedd◂/  someone who is conceited or big-headed is too proud of their own achievements or abilities, in a way that annoys other people:
examples: tự phụ kiêu ngạo
▪ You’re the most conceited, selfish person I’ve ever met!
▪ I know this sounds big-headed, but I’ve always been good at French.

children.name: vain
children.definition: /veɪn/  someone who is vain thinks they are very good-looking, special, or intelligent:
examples: kiêu ngạo, tự phụ, tự đắc
▪ She’s a vain girl who is always thinking about her figure.
▪ I am vain enough to want to look good, but not to style my hair and paint my toenails.

children.name: pleased with yourself
children.definition: /ˈpliːzd wɪð jɔːʳself/  feelingunreasonablyproud of yourself, especially because you think you have done something clever:
examples: hài lòng về mình
▪ I had made a big profit on the deal and was feeling inordinately pleased with myself.
▪ After deceiving us all like that, she went away, no doubt very pleased with herself.

children.name: arrogant
children.definition: /ˈærəgənt/  someone who is arrogant behaves as if their opinions are more important than other people’s, and thinks that they are always right:tự phụ kiêu ngạo
examples: ▪ You are a rude and arrogant young man.
▪ his arrogant disregard for other people’s opinions
arrogantly[adverb]tự phụ kiêu ngạo
▪ They arrogantly assumed that their form of democracy was better than anyone else’s.

children.name: smug
children.definition: /smʌg/  quietly pleased with yourself in an unpleasant and annoying way, because you think you are in a better position than other people:chảnh chọe
examples: ▪ Lawson comes over as smug and arrogant, but in fact he’s quite a decent man.
▪ If you knew, which I’m sure you did judging from your smug expression, why didn’t you tell me?
smug about:chảnh chọe về
▪ I felt very smug about not wasting paper.
smugly[adverb]chảnh chọe
▪ ‘I’m getting a motorcycle soon,’ he announced smugly. ‘My dad’s buying me one for my eighteenth birthday.’

children.name: self-satisfied
children.definition: /self ˈsætsfaɪd/  someone who is self-satisfied thinks that they are very clever, very successful etc, often without good reason, and shows this in an annoying way:tự mãn
examples: ▪ Doyle’s self-satisfied smile irritated Haworth.
▪ He was in his early 40s and had the self-satisfied air of someone who has achieved fame and success.
▪ What makes a second-rate actress like Jean so self-satisfied, so over-confident?

children.name: be full of yourself
children.definition: /biː ˈfʊl əv jɔːʳˌself/  spoken to be always talking about your abilities and achievements and never show any interest in those of other people:tự đắc
examples: ▪ She’s a good-looking woman, but too full of herself for my liking.
▪ He was too full of himself to care about anyone else.

children.name: think you’re it
children.definition: alsofancy yourselfBritish /ˌθɪŋk jɔːr ˈɪt, ˈfænsi jɔːʳself/  spoken informal use this when you think someone is too proud of their abilities or appearance:ảo tưởng sức mạnh
examples: ▪ You think you’re it, don’t you? Well you’re not!
▪ Like most young professional footballers, he really fancied himself.

children.name: let st go to your head
children.definition: let something go to your head/let something ˌgəʊ tə jɔːʳ ˈhed/  to start behaving as if you are very important as a result of something, for example a success or being praised by someone:để thứ gì làm mờ mắt
examples: ▪ It’s not surprising that young rock bands let success go to their heads.
▪ I know you did well, but don’t let it go to your head -- the hardest part’s still to come.

children.name: get too big for your boots
children.definition: British /too big for your britchesAmerican /get tuː ˌbɪg fəʳ jɔːʳ ˈbuːts, tuː ˌbɪg fəʳ jɔːʳ ˈbrɪtʃz/  informal to start thinking you are more important than you really are, especially because you have been successful in something:quá kiêu ngạo tự phụ
examples: ▪ Bonaparte wasn’t all that bad. He was just a soldier who got too big for his boots.

children.name: sb who thinks they are better than other people
snob
children.definition: /snɒbǁsnɑːb/  someone who thinks that they are better than people from a lower social class:
examples: kẻ hợm hĩnh
▪ Since going to university he’d become a snob, embarrassed by his family.
▪ I don’t want to sound like a snob, but I found the decor vulgar.

children.name: stuck-up
children.definition: /ˌstʌk ˈʌp◂/  informal someone who is stuck-up thinks that they are better than other people, and behaves in a proud, unfriendly way:
examples: hợm mình trịnh thượng
▪ The children who go to that school are a bit stuck-up.
▪ a pompous, stuck-up little man

children.name: pompous
children.definition: /ˈpɒmpəsǁˈpɑːm-/  someone who is pompous tries to sound important, especially by using very long orformalwords:
examples: khoa trương, vênh vang
▪ She found him pompous and annoying.
▪ The headteacher gave a pompous speech about ‘the values of learning’.

children.name: snobbish
children.definition: /ˈsnɒbɪʃǁˈsnɑː-/  someone who is snobbish thinks that they are better than people from a lower class, so that they will not be friendly with them or do the things they do:hợm hĩnh
examples: ▪ Some people find her snobbish, but she’s really just shy.
▪ his snobbish attitude to soap operas on TV
snobbish about:hợm hĩnh với
▪ She’s very snobbish about people who live in the suburbs.
snobbery[uncountable noun]thứ màu mè hợm hĩnh
▪ To say that working class people are all the same is sheer snobbery is being very snobbish.

children.name: self-important
children.definition: /ˌself ɪmˈpɔːʳtənt◂/  thinking you are much more important than you really are:tự cao
examples: ▪ As a waiter, he had grown to despise self-important customers.
▪ He was one of those self-important little officials who made everyone call him ‘Sir’.
self-importance[uncountable noun]sự tự cao
▪ He strutted into the room, full of his own self-importance.

children.name: haughty
children.definition: /ˈhɔːti/  someone who is haughty behaves in a proud and very unfriendly way, as if they think other people are completely unimportant:ngạo mạn
examples: ▪ People thought of him as being haughty and difficult to talk to.
▪ Jessica turned away with a haughty look on her face.
haughtily[adverb]ngạo mạn
▪ She refused his request, haughtily explaining that such things were beneath her.

children.name: snotty
children.definition: /ˈsnɒtiǁˈsnɑː-/  informal rude and unfriendly because you think you are better than other people:khinh khỉnh, kiêu kỳ
examples: ▪ The hotel receptionist was a bit snotty to me this morning.
▪ a bunch of snotty rich kids

children.name: a feeling of respect for yourself
self-respect
children.definition: /ˌself rɪˈspekt/  a feeling of respect and confidence in yourself and in your abilities:
examples: lòng tự trọng
▪ It is difficult to keep your self-respect when you have been unemployed for a long time
▪ Serious illness often results in a loss of confidence and self-respect.
self-respectnoun[ U ]lòng tự trọng, thái độ tự trọng
respect for yourself which shows that you value yourself
_He felt what he was being asked to do took away his dignity and self-respect.

children.name: dignity
children.definition: /ˈdɪgnɪti, ˈdɪgnəti/  the ability to behave in acalmway that shows that you respect yourself, even in difficult situations:
examples: lòng tự trọng, phẩm giá
do something with dignity: làm cái gì đó vớilòng tự trọng, phẩm giá
▪ Very sick people should be allowed to die with dignity.
lose your dignity
mấtlòng tự trọng, phẩm giá
▪ She lost her home and all her money, but she never lost her dignity.

children.name: dignified
children.definition: /ˈdɪgnɪfaɪd, ˈdɪgnəfaɪd/  behaving in a calm way, even in a difficult situation, so that other people respect and admire you:
examples: có phẩm giá , đáng tôn trọng
▪ She was a quiet, dignified old lady.
▪ Jo listened to their criticisms in dignified silence.

children.name: pride
children.definition: /praɪd/  the feeling that you deserve to be respected by other people - use this especially when this feeling is sostrongthat someone finds itdifficultto admit theyneed helpor that they arewrong:
examples: tự trọng
▪ He has too much pride to say he’s sorry.
▪ Her pride would not allow her to ask for help.
hurt somebody’s pride
làm tổn thương lòng tự trọng của ai đó
▪ We don’t like failing - it hurts our pride.
pridenounRESPECT FOR YOURSELF
[ U ] your feelings of your own worth and respect for yourself
_She has too much pride to accept any help.
_The country's national pride has been dented (= damaged) by its sporting failures.

children.name: the feeling you have when you are proud of sth
pride
children.definition: /praɪd/  the feeling of being proud because of something special you have achieved, someone special you are connected with etc:
examples: niềm tự hào
▪ Chinese students have a sense of national pride.
do something with pride: làm cái gì đó vớiniềm tự hào
▪ He talked with great pride about his father’s work.
pride in
tự hào về
▪ Her pride in her daughter knew no bounds.
bursting with pridefeeling extremely proud : tràn đầy niềm tự hào
▪ Bursting with pride, she stood up to receive her prize.
pridenounSATISFACTIONsự kiêu hãnh, sự hãnh diện
[ U ] a feeling of pleasure and satisfaction that you get because you or people connected with you have done or got something good
_She felt a great sense of pride as she watched him accept the award.
_He felt such pride walking his little daughter down the street.

children.name: to think you are better than other people
look down on
children.definition: /lʊk ˈdaʊn ɒn/  if you look down on other people, you think you are better or more important then them:
examples: khinh thường , khinh miệt
▪ He looks down on anyone who hasn’t had a college education.

children.name: be beneath
children.definition: /biː bɪˈniːθ/  if it is beneath you to do something or to talk to someone, you think you are much too important to do it:không xứng
examples: ▪ Do you think you could make the tea for once -- or is that beneath you!
be beneath to do something
không xứng để làm cái gì đó
▪ She was surprised to learn that he didn’t think it was beneath him to help around the house.

children.name: think you’re too good for
children.definition: /ˌθɪŋk jɔːʳ tuː ˈgʊd fɔːʳ/  if you say that someone thinks they are too good for a particular kind of work or for a particular person, you mean they are too proud to do that kind of work or to spend time with that person:nghĩ rằng bạn quá giỏi so với
examples: ▪ I suppose you think you’re too good for us now you’ve inherited a fortune.
▪ So you think you’re too good for training college?

children.name: arrogance
children.definition: /ˈærəgəns/  an unreasonable pride in your own abilities or qualities, which makes you behave rudely, as if other people were of no importance or interest:sự kiêu ngạo
examples: ▪ ‘I ought to be in charge here,’ said Jack with simple arrogance.
▪ His arrogance and unwillingness to learn from others prevent him from being an effective member of the team.

children.name: conceit
children.definition: /kənˈsiːt/  too much pride in your own abilities, appearance, or qualities, especially following a success which has made you behave as if you are very important:tính tự phụ
examples: ▪ After scoring the winning goal he almost danced along the road in his satisfaction and conceit.
▪ I got so sick of his conceit that I threw the damn trophy out.

children.name: vanity
children.definition: /ˈvænɪti, ˈvænəti/  great pride in yourself so that you are always thinking about yourself, especially about your appearance:tính kiêu căng
examples: ▪ His life is driven by vanity. He has to drive around in the most expensive car and wear the best designer clothes.
▪ Jo’s vanity wouldn’t let her walk past a mirror without looking in it.

children.name: proudly
children.definition: adverbmột cách tự hào; một cách hãnh diện
examples: in a proud way
_He proudly held out his trophy for us to admire.
_Elaine and Ian Gibson proudly announce the birth of their son, John Maurice.
_There were photographs of all her children proudly displayed on the mantelpiece.
